floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Burton Bradstock river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of low lying areas is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride   
 River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated on Thursday, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected now.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning before 09:00am

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Gillingham Le Neubourg Way river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, their is a risk of localised flooding.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton   
River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Thursday, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Clay Coton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 16/03/22.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Leicestershire, Lincolnshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, Rutland, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Welland catchment area. This means that the River Welland and River Jordan are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to these rivers from this evening, Wednesday, 16th March onwards. We expect these rivers to remain high throughout the next 24 hours. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for  blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Thursday, 17th March, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Trowbridge river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 19:00 and overnight tonight and into tomorrow, 17/03/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Westbury Road (A363) at Yarnbrook, Hawkeridge Road at Horse Bridge, Shallow Wagon Lane at Heywood and West Ashton Road at Trowbridge.   
We expect river levels to continue to rise throughout the night from Wednesday 16/03/22 and into Thursday 17/03/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and in contact with community flood wardens and volunteers.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated 09:30, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and its tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river, from the evening of Wednesday, 16th March onwards. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Thursday, 17th March, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Nuneaton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening, 16/03/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to rise until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low-lying farmland and roads is expected from 21:00 this evening, 16/03/22. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 2 hours. We expect river levels to begin falling at approximately 07:00 tomorrow morning, 17/03/22, but the risk of flooding may remain throughout the day.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Glen catchment. This means that the River East Glen and the River West Glen are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the evening of Wednesday, 16th March onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Nuneaton river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall throughout today 16/03/2022. Consequently, flooding of property is expected overnight and into tomorrow morning 17/03/2022. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning 17/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please move family, pets, possessions, valuables and cars to safety and activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon gauge at Bradford on Avon  as a result of heavy rainfall, with over 15mm of rain fallen in the last 24 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, River Avon at Bradford on Avon, River Avon at Bathford and Semington Brook at Semington are rising through this evening (the 16th March 2022). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

This message will be updated on Thursday the 17th March 2022, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to effect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.

River levels have risen at the Great Somerford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall, with over 15mm of rain fallen in the last 24 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, at Brokenborough and Fosseway are rising through this evening (the 16th March 2022). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.   

This message will be updated on Thursday the 17th March 2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Cappenham river gauge as a result of the rainfall this afternoon and into this evening. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible over Wednesday night, 16/03/2022.  

We expect flooding to affect River Tove from Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook.
 
Further rainfall is forecast continue into the night, 16/03/2022 with drier, brighter conditions expected over the next 5 days. We expect river levels to remain high into the morning of 17/03/2022 and begin to fall during the course of the day. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  
  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/2022.

items.description: Minor watercourses of the South Forty Foot Drain
items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Forty Foot Drain tributaries catchment. This means that the minor watercourses of South Forty Foot Drain are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to these rivers from this evening on Wednesday, 16th March onwards. We expect these rivers to remain high throughout the next 24 hours. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Thursday, 17th March or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sence from Temple Mill to Sheepy Magna
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Temple Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property is expected overnight, 17/03/22.     
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/22, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Blackwater is high and rising. In the last 14 hours, 17mm of rain has been recorded at Romsey. This is a significant amount in a short time. This morning (17/03/2022), water levels will be very high around the mill building. Some minor impact flooding may also affect land, fields and roads at West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Property flooding is not expected. Rain has now cleared the area. The river will peak around 04:00 this morning (17/03/2022). Dry weather is forecast from today (17/03/2022) until Sunday (20/03/2022). This will allow the river time to recover to its normal level. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. We will update this Flood Alert by 11:00 on 17/03/2022.
